texts.definition: Roles people can receive or take in relation to each other based on gameplay features.
markups: <style="Definition">Roles people can receive or take in relation to each other based on gameplay features.</style>

Playing games is often a social activity. While players may take their social relations with them to a game, many games put different players in different social positions primarily due to different abilities to affect the gameplay. These positions make players take new <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> which are based upon the gameplay structures of the game.

Note: ''While Bartle's paper Hearts, Clubs, Diamonds, Spades: Players Who suit MUDs does present categories for gamers that do have aspects of social roles, these describe player preferences. The pattern described here looks at how gameplay features can evoke Social Roles.''
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Classical <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> put players in the role of each other's enemies. Other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style>, and some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style>, are mainly cooperative but make some players ''traitors''. Examples include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Shadows%20over%20Camelot">Shadows over Camelot</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Resistance">The Resistance</link></style>.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> require players to choose classes. These give players specific abilities but these abilities also make certain <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> more natural, e.g. clerics in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> have abilities to help other characters. Examples of other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> that do this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Apocalypse%20World">Apocalypse World</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant:%20%C3%85r%20Noll">Mutant: År Noll</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Everquest%20series">Everquest series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. Similarly, class-based online <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enemy%20Territory:%20Quake%20Wars">Enemy Territory: Quake Wars</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style> provide players with different functional roles which also infer <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

Having <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> is a basic requirement for <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> to be possible but <style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> are even better foundations since there players have a large group of other players to take on roles with. Unless players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat</link></style> or  <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> are also necessary for <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> to function. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Organizations">Social Organizations</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> are general ways of grouping players together which may further incline <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> to emerge but without specifically influencing which roles do so. <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>, or the possibility to develop <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, link the <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> directly to specific gameplay skills. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Classes">Character Classes</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> can be used for forcing players into taking <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style>.

<style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> moves the <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> from being based on the players to being based on their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> but can just as well provide these roles. The use of <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> or successfully motivating players to adhere to <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> further strengthens the likelihood that players while adopt <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> for their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> also opens up for some more specific patterns based on the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> roles, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Brokering">Brokering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Match-Making">Match-Making</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcast">Outcast</link></style>.

Just as <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> may be necessary for <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Communication%20Abilities">Limited Communication Abilities</link></style> may work against the pattern (but see the outcast role below). <style="Link"><link="player-anonymity">Player Anonymity</link></style> may make <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> less present or more difficult to take, so both <style="Link"><link="enforced-player-anonymity">Enforced Player Anonymity</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="possibility-anonymity">Possibility of Anonymity</link></style> work against <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style>.

Besides these pattern, what gameplay design patterns hinder or support <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> depend heavily on the specifics of individual <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style>. Examples of possible <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> are:

* Banned – players not allowed to play the game due to <style="Link"><link="player-kicking">Player Kicking</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Excluding%20Groups">Excluding Groups</link></style> can provide this for parts of a game (e.g. not letting players participate in a raid on an <style="Link"><link="instances">Instance</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>).

* Outcasts – players excluded from social interaction with the other players. Allowing players to set <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Communication%20Abilities">Limited Communication Abilities</link></style> for other players is one way of achieving this while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Excluding%20Groups">Excluding Groups</link></style> can hinder actual gameplay.

* Recluses – players willingly isolating themselves from social interaction with other players. <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style> offers one way of supporting recluses, and <style="Link"><link="tiered-participation">Tiered Participation</link></style> another.

* Motivators – players providing or advocating activities and experiences in the game without seeking any in-game benefit. <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extras">Extras</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Referees">Referees</link></style> can support this role. <style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style> may give these the possibility that players get the experiences they can handle or wish to have which otherwise would not have happened due to <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>.

* Negotiators – players negotiating between two other players. Quite obviously, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> may support this role (if a player can negotiate between two other players that is), but <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> are also good candidates. More specific patterns related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> include handling <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="shared-resources">Resources</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Rewards</link></style> and reaching agreements regarding <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distributions">Player-Decided Distributions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Results">Results</link></style>. While in many cases the negotiator may be directly affect by this, he or she will also have to deal with several other players' opinions. Negotiators may also help others in <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, but this may be a dominator masking as a negotiator. Setting up <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Temporary%20Alliances">Temporary Alliances</link></style> or maintaining <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Secret%20Alliances">Secret Alliances</link></style> may also suit negotiators.

* Mediators – players performing actions for other players, either through their own actions or by taking over other players' possibilities to influence the game. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Proxy%20Players">Proxy Players</link></style> can allow for this, but just as they can support motivators, the use of <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style> can also support mediators. A less active form of this is that of facilitators, which may not be seen as players; <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> is an example of this.

* Helpers – players actively helping other players perform actions in the game. An explicit need for helpers can be achieved through using <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> can do so without necessarily limiting other players. <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> can let players help each other while <style="Link"><link="coaches">Coaches</link></style> is a more passive way of allowing players to be helpers.

* Violators – players trying to affect other players’ gameplay against their will through explicit actions. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> between players and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Directly%20Aggressive%20Actions">Directly Aggressive Actions</link></style> are obvious ways of letting players be violators but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="ninja-looting">Ninja Looting</link></style> can have less impact on the other players' possibilities to continue playing.

* Dominators – players trying to influence other players to perform specific actions for the player’s own in-game benefits. <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style> and the possibility of appointing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Scapegoats">Scapegoats</link></style> can support this as does opportunities for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style> to set up <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayals</link></style>. Dominators may also arise from games that have <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conspiring">Conspiring</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirectly%20Aggressive%20Actions">Indirectly Aggressive Actions</link></style> may also work since dominators can be uses them to influence players without directly confronting them; <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style> is an example of this and can make players into low intensity dominators while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cartel%20Formation">Cartel Formation</link></style> a somewhat more direct one. Dominators can also help others in <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> by pretending to be negotiators. Two other patterns that fit both negotiators and dominators are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Secret%20Alliances">Secret Alliances</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Temporary%20Alliances">Temporary Alliances</link></style>.

* Exhibitionists – players performing actions in the game to gain the other players’ attention or simply <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bragging">Bragging</link></style> about previous actions. <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ranking%20Systems">Ranking Systems</link></style> can provide exhibitionists with material to brag about. <style="Link"><link="tiered-participation">Tiered Participation</link></style> can let those that want to have extra attention placed on them receive this and as can the act of <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> can let exhibitionists show off in any gameplay activity that supports these.

While <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> can emerge from the uses mentioned in the list above, <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> can also be used to modify already present <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> in a game as well.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>
Allowing <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> can make <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> easier to maintain as well as negotiate.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> provides a structure and often encouragement for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> and thereby support for a sense of <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style>. When players have freedom of which <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> they should have, this is a type of <style="Link"><link="role-selection">Role Selection</link></style> and can provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>. Fitting <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> well can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>. Many <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> requires <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, and negotiating whom should have what <style="CurrentLink">Social Role</style> can require <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> in itself.

There are some potentially negative aspects of <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style>. Besides the ones associated with typically "negative" roles, e.g. banned, some roles may have less to do during gameplay, causing <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, unless the frequency of the importance of these are especially promoted. Further, <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> are likely to let players known more about each other making <style="Link"><link="actor-detachment">Actor Detachment</link></style> problematic.

Players' wish to discuss <style="CurrentLink">Social Roles</style> and the subjects they relate to can increase the level of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> in a game. It can also lead to <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style> if the game also has <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>.
